results.title: Growing up in Australia: 1901-1946
results.brief_description: This series, written by Sue Fabian and Morag Loh, looks specifically at the place of children in Australia’s history, using early drawings and photographs to draw interesting observations about the role of children in the building of the new colony. This particular program looks at the period from the early 1900s to 1946. By the turn of the century primary education was available for all children and new childrens’ hospitals were being established in all states. Children now enjoyed more leisure activities, although their games were very much gender based and dependant on whether they lived in the bush or city. During World War 1, children played war games and young men lied about their age in order to enlist, while other children became involved in the peace movement. The program shows the change in the optimistic mood of the young country as devastating losses of Australian troops occurred overseas. The Jazz Age further impacted on lifestyles and the 1920s also saw the migration of thousands of poor and orphaned children from Britain under the “populate or perish” notion. When the Depression developed, many families were malnourished and children were put out to work, as employers could pay them lower wages than they paid adults. This period of history also saw the establishment of kindergartens, health centres, the Scouting and Guiding Movement and developments in the education of girls, particularly in the private school system.

results.title: Growing up in a scary world (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles, Jeanne H. Block and Thelma Harms
results.brief_description: Filmed in a nursery school group of 4 and 5 year olds in the spring of 1970 during a time of crisis in the adult world. The staff provided a small sandbox with a number of small toys in order to see how young children use spontaneous play in a time of stress. The results lend themselves to discussion on many issues.

results.title: Growing up female
results.brief_description: This film gives graphic illustration of the kind of conditioning that women undergo in society, in an attempt to examine and question the whole framework of the women’s role. Women from various age-groups are presented, all of them revealing in some degree their mental conditioning. Advertising media are viewed as instrumental in this process. The film raises important questions as to the depth of the problem and the possibilities of liberating women in the present social order.

results.title: Growing up at St Giles
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Government Film Unit and Andrew Steane
results.brief_description: The care and treatment of physically handicapped children at St. Giles home, Launceston. Boarders and day pupils attend the Home, receiving physiotherapy, schooling and the individual attention and group activities they need to overcome difficulties and stand on their own feet. The types of disabilities treated and examples of how former pupils have settled into ordinary employment.

results.title: Growing together
results.brief_description: Parents of children aged from two to five years speak about the problems and joys of dealing with children at this age. Provides some insight into the nature of child development during this period. Companion film toe “One and one makes three”.

results.title: Growing pains
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
One of a series of films that examines the history of immigration to Australia. This film covers the period 1901-1945 and looks at the effects that the depression and the two world wars had on immigration.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: Growing old
results.brief_description: The problems presented by an aging population, illustrated by real-life case histories. The contribution of the welfare and medical services throughout Britain to the geriatric problem is emphasised, and the film touches on all facets of life among the elderly, including family relationships, economic factors and health.

results.title: Growing girls
results.brief_description: Aims at instructing pre-adolescent and adolescent girls in the physiology and hygiene of menstruation, emphasizing the normality of the process. The story is woven around 13-year old Mary and is introduced by showing her and her friend on the school playing field. Photographic shots are used to show how all young creatures grow up - chickens, calves, tadpoles, and humans. Animated diagrams illustrate the physiology of menstruation and the development of the human foetus. Photography is then used to demonstrate the hygiene of menstruation and the reasonable precautions necessary while menstruating.

results.title: Growing dollars
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells and Tina Viljoen
results.brief_description: The dramatic increase in grain production during the ‘Green Revolution’ in the mid-1960’s, created an important agricultural advance in many Third World countries. However, it had wide repercussions on all types of farming. Large scale mechanised farms began to take over smaller farms, forcing small and tenant farmers who lost their land to migrate to the cities, where they swelled the ranks of the urban unemployed. This documentary is a look at ‘agri-business’, a term to describe the multi-national corporations that are attempting to create a world agricultural system in which everything they produce is for customers in the already wealthy countries. (Awards: Berlin)
